journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Multilevel framework for optimization of lightweight structures

author-notes.corresp: *Cardiff School of Engineering, Cardiff University, Queen’s Buildings, The Parade, Cardiff, CF24 3AA, UK.email: FeatherstonCA@cardiff.ac.uk

abstract.p: Optimization of aerospace and lightweight structures, such as aircraft wings, is typically best carried out via a multilevel process. This becomes necessary owing to the complexity of the structure and potentially very large numbers of design variables. While more conventional analysis and design procedures are often based on the computationally expensive finite element method, specialist software, such as the ‘exact’ strip program VICONOPT, provides faster and more efficient alternatives for structural components such as wing panels. With ever-increasing computational power, different software solutions can be integrated by means of robust and easy-to-use interfaces, allowing the user to benefit from more versatile optimization environments. The computer program Viconopt MLO establishes a multilevel framework for optimization by interfacing the panel analysis and design software VICONOPT and the finite element software MSC/NASTRAN. In this paper the underlying principles of the optimization procedure in Viconopt MLO are described, and the software's capability is demonstrated through the optimization of a composite aircraft wing.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The design and optimization of aerospace structures is a very complicated task. The complexity of the structural configuration, combined with the wide range of loading and boundary conditions, leads to the need for a multilevel optimization approach.

Early work (mainly in the USA) included multilevel minimum weight design of wing [1], fuselage [2] and stiffened box sections [3, 4]. Sobieszczanski-Sobieski et al. developed methods for structural sizing by multilevel decomposition [5] and generalized multilevel optimization [6]. More recently, Ragon et al. [7] developed a methodology for multilevel optimization of an aircraft wing, in which optimum weights obtained by the panel design program PASCO [8] were used to construct a response surface for use by the global optimizer ADOP [9]. A similar approach was adopted by Balabanov et al. [10] for two-level aerodynamic-structural optimization. Liu et al. [11] proposed a two-level optimization procedure, also based on response surface methodology, for composite wing design subject to strength and buckling constraints.

During the 1990s, research into the optimization of aerospace structures was carried out by the Group for Aeronautical Research and Technology in Europe (GARTEUR), which recommended the development of multidisciplinary and multilevel design software [12].

While the widely used finite element method (FEM) is very versatile, allowing structures with a wide range of loading and boundary conditions to be analysed, it comes at a high computational cost. This is particularly the case when performing design optimizations involving large numbers of design variables, which requires many finite element analyses to be carried out.

The specialist analysis and optimum design software VICONOPT [13] is based on an ‘exact’ strip method, and so allows prismatic aerospace structural components, such as aircraft wing panels, to be analysed in a much faster and more efficient way. However, while the software can analyse and design integral structural components whose cross-sections and loading are longitudinally invariant, it is unable to design a general three-dimensional structure subject to complex external loading. Typically, finite element analyses of the overall structural system are required to determine the loads acting on the individual structural components prior to any VICONOPT analysis and optimization. Despite this and some approximations required by the modelling process, VICONOPT has been used for analysis and design purposes, in both industry and academia, for more than two decades.

This paper describes the development of new interface software, Viconopt MLO, which aims to provide an efficient solution for the optimization of typical aerospace structures, such as composite aircraft wings, by combining MSC/NASTRAN [14] finite element analysis and VICONOPT optimization, so overcoming the shortcomings of both of the individual approaches identified above.

sec.title: 2 VICONOPT
sec.p:
VICONOPT [13] is a panel analysis and optimum design computer program, which incorporates the earlier programs VIPASA (Vibration and Instability of Plate Assemblies including Shear and Anisotropy) [15] and VICON (VIPASA with Constraints) [16]. VICONOPT covers elastic buckling, postbuckling, and free vibration of prismatic plate assemblies, and provides an efficient design tool in structural optimization. In contrast to the conventional FEM, the analysis uses a transcendental stiffness matrix derived from an analytical or numerical solution of the governing differential equations of the component plates. For any longitudinally invariant loading combination (of longitudinal, transverse, in-plane shear, and pressure loads), critical buckling loads, undamped natural frequencies, and mode shapes can be found with certainty, using procedures based on the Wittrick–Williams algorithm [17]. Typical sections which VICONOPT can analyse, and a typical component plate showing in-plane loading are given in Figs 1 and 2. Fig. 1
Typical sections which VICONOPT can analyse Fig. 2
Component plate with in-plane loading

sec.title: 2.1 ‘Exact’ strip method and Wittrick–Williams algorithm
sec.p: VICONOPT analyses are based on an ‘exact’ strip method which assumes a continuous distribution of stiffness over the structure rather than discretized stiffnesses at nodal points, as is the case for the more widely used FEM. The exact strip method is based on solutions to the partial differential equations, which govern the in-plane and out-of plane deformation of the component plates. Analytical [15] or numerical [18] solution procedures are used to determine the member stiffness matrices, which are subsequently assembled into the global stiffness matrix K for the overall structure. K consists of transcendental, and thus highly non-linear, functions of the load factor or frequency [19]. Buckling and vibration analyses therefore require the solution of a transcendental eigenvalue problem. VICONOPT makes use of the Wittrick–Williams algorithm [17, 20] which allows such eigenvalues (i.e. critical buckling load factors or natural frequencies of free vibration) to be found with absolute certainty by an iterative search.

VICONOPT assumes either that the panel has simply supported ends, or is infinitely long with periodically repeating supports. This latter model has been shown [13] to be consistent with the continuity conditions arising in typical aerospace structures.

sec.title: 2.2 VICONOPT design optimization
sec.p:
The panel design strategy of VICONOPT includes continuous [21, 22] and (optionally) discrete [23] optimization, as illustrated in Fig. 3. Any set of plate widths, layer thicknesses and ply orientations can be chosen as independent design variables, while other dimensions may be held fixed or linked to the independent design variables. Such linking maintains geometric consistency, while reducing computational time owing to the smaller number of independent design variables. In aerospace structural design, most composite components have a symmetric and balanced lay-up, which can also be exploited to significantly reduce the number of design variables. Panels are designed to minimize mass (or an alternative cost function [24]), subject to initial buckling, postbuckling, material strength, overall stiffness, and/or geometric constraints. Fig. 3
Panel design strategy showing continuous and discrete design phase

Continuous optimization (steps 1–8 and 12 of Fig. 3) is performed using the gradient-based optimizer CONMIN [25, 26] (step 5) coupled with a stabilization (thickness factoring) procedure [22] (steps 2 and 6), which ensures a just stable configuration. Move limits are adjusted intelligently by the program (step 4) to seek the best starting point for the next sizing cycle. Because the stiffness matrix varies transcendentally with the load factor, the buckling sensitivities cannot easily be obtained analytically, and so are found (step 3) by an efficient estimation technique [22].

The discrete design phase (DDP) (steps 9–11 of Fig. 3) is invoked whenever some or all of the design variables are restricted to take discrete values [23, 27]. Its approach differs from that of many other methods, in that it does not interact with the continuous phase. Instead, it follows the continuous phase, using the continuous optimum solution as a starting point, and thus provides an efficient means of locating a feasible discrete solution close to the continuous optimum.

sec.title: 3 VICONOPT MLO
sec.p: Viconopt MLO [28, 29] has been developed to provide a multilevel framework for optimization of lightweight structures, such as composite aircraft wings. By means of a robust and easy-to-use windows interface, the software links one of the most widely used finite element solvers, MSC/NASTRAN [14], with the fast and efficient design capabilities of VICONOPT [13]. MSC/NASTRAN models of plate assemblies are readily translated into a VICONOPT format by Viconopt MLO. Using the MSC/NASTRAN input file and initial results of an existing finite element static analysis, VICONOPT optimization models are generated for any of the component plates (or assemblies thereof). Most of VICONOPT's existing analysis and design features have been implemented in Viconopt MLO for user selection.

The optimization process is of an iterative nature, and is based on the interaction between models at the MSC/NASTRAN and VICONOPT levels. These two levels are commonly referred to as the system level and the panel level, respectively. In the current version of Viconopt MLO, design changes are only made at panel level, and are automatically fed back into the finite element model at system level. Owing to these design changes the load-carrying capacity of the overall structure is altered, and stress re-distributions occur, which are determined at the beginning of each new optimization cycle. The VICONOPT models at the panel level are then updated and the process is repeated until an overall mass convergence criterion is met.

In addition to providing a multilevel framework for optimization, Viconopt MLO has been developed as a pre-/post-processor for conventional VICONOPT models. These can either be generated from scratch or imported from MSC/NASTRAN. Where models have been imported from MSC/NASTRAN, any additional parameters necessary for a VICONOPT analysis or optimization can be specified in Viconopt MLO. This approach avoids the need for text input files to be generated manually, as has been previously the case, so that models can be assembled, analysed, and optimized much more quickly and efficiently.

sec.title: 3.1 Multilevel interface for optimization
sec.p:
Figure 4 gives a detailed flowchart representation of the optimization procedure adopted by Viconopt MLO. It is important to note that the software interfaces directly with MSC/NASTRAN, making the procedures for the data transfer independent of any pre-/post- processor used to generate the MSC/NASTRAN model. Fig. 4
Flowchart of optimization procedure using Viconopt MLO

For the work presented in this paper, MSC/PATRAN [30] has been used as the pre-/post-processor, but could be readily replaced by any other software package available. Once an MSC/NASTRAN input file (.bdf) has been generated for the overall structure at system level, an initial finite element static analysis needs to be carried out in order to determine the internal load distribution across the structure. All the structural components that constitute plates in a VICONOPT model must be modelled as plates at the system level and must be assigned individual property cards, so that all the model information required to specify the optimization problem at the panel level can be translated by the ‘MSC/NASTRAN to VICONOPT’ converter in Viconopt MLO. Any additional parameters required to create the panel models may be specified using the preprocessing capabilities of Viconopt MLO.

When all the VICONOPT panel models have been set up, Viconopt MLO automatically generates the VICONOPT input files (.dat). The panels are separately analysed and optimized by VICONOPT, and two results files (.vres and .u11) are created. The .vres files contain all of the results from the panel optimizations, as well as various other pieces of information which can be requested by the user. The .u11 file contains the optimization results, including the final values of the design variables and dependent variables in a format suitable for re-input into VICONOPT.

The next stage of the process uses the ‘VICONOPT to MSC/NASTRAN’ converter to feed all the design changes made by VICONOPT back into the original finite element model, which is subsequently re-analysed. The stress re-distributions following these design changes are determined, and a new output file (.f06) is created. On the basis of the .u11 and new .f06 files, all the VICONOPT models are updated and re-optimized. Viconopt MLO repeats the above procedure until a final convergence criterion on the overall mass of the structure is achieved (e.g. less than 1 per cent change in mass between successive cycles).

sec.title: 3.2 Load transfer between system and panel levels
sec.p: Owing to the nature of the buckling analysis in VICONOPT, which requires the loading on structural components to be longitudinally invariant, a number of approximations are necessary for the load transfer between system and panel levels. These depend very much on the type of elements used and their specific properties, which must be taken into account. Element forces and stresses are output by MSC/NASTRAN according to the element's individual coordinate system. Any pre- and post-processor needs to transform these results into a global context for the overall structure. In a similar way, Viconopt MLO translates the results into the corresponding VICONOPT format. The work presented in this paper uses QUAD4 shell elements [31], which have continuity of strain through the thickness of a laminated plate.

MSC/NASTRAN provides average values for the principal stresses on the top and bottom surfaces of each element. On the basis of these stresses, the corresponding axial and bending loads are approximated for the components in a VICONOPT model.

The loading acting on the individual panels of an aircraft wing is primarily owing to the bending moments generated for the overall wing. For example, in the case of a simple uplift the top panels of the wing will go into compression and the bottom panels into tension. The relative amounts of compression and tension generated depend on the position of the wing's overall neutral axis. While involving some approximation for a composite structure, a linear stress distribution based on beam bending theory is assumed over the cross-section of the wing.

For a VICONOPT panel model, the effect of the global bending of the wing needs to be approximated in terms of a longitudinally invariant total axial force and a bending moment, Fxpanel and Mypanel, as well as transverse and shear stress components per unit length for the panel's component plates, fyplate and fxyplate. This is done on the basis of the stresses determined by MSC/NASTRAN for the individual elements that comprise the plate.

The normal x and y stresses acting on an element can each be represented by the scenario shown in Fig. 5, which has been simplified by assuming continuity of stress through the thickness of the element. Fig. 5
Simplified element stress distribution

σax is determined as the stress at the element's profile axis. There is a balance of material to either side of the profile axis. In the case of pure bending, the profile axis coincides with the element's neutral axis, and the bending stress is equal to zero at this axis. Where bending and axial stresses have been combined, it follows that (1) where σt and σb are the stresses at the top and bottom surface of the element as calculated by MSC/NASTRAN, and zt and zb are the distances between the top and bottom surfaces and the element's profile axis. The axial force per unit width is now approximated as (2)
With σax known, the bending stresses σflex is determined (see Fig. 5) as (3)
The bending moment per unit length acting on the element is now calculated from (4)
The above procedure allows the calculation of the axial forces per unit length, fxel and fyel, and bending moments per unit length, mxel and myel, in the element's local x and y directions.
The shear force per unit length acting on an element is calculated as (5) where τt and τb are the shear stresses in the top and bottom surfaces of the element.

Assuming that all elements are rectangular, the total forces and bending moments acting on each element are then found from (6a) (6b) (6c) (6d) where bel and λel are the width and length of the element, respectively.

Before determining the VICONOPT loading for the overall panel and its component plates, the element forces and moments are transformed from the local element system to the global system (denoted by overbars) using a standard coordinate transformation.
The total longitudinal load and bending moment acting on a panel are then calculated as (7a) (7b)

The shear and transverse stress resultants per unit length for the individual component plates in the panel are given by (8a) (8b) where Nelx is the number of elements along the length of the panel and Nelp is the number of elements in the component plate.

Note that the approach adopted for equations (6) and (8) assumes that all elements have the same length λel. When dealing with prismatic plate assemblies, this will usually be the case. Where elements are of different lengths, a weighted average needs to be determined.

sec.title: 4 APPLICATIONS
sec.p:
In order to demonstrate the proposed multilevel framework, a study was conducted into the optimization of a simplified representation of a composite aircraft wing using the GARTEUR benchmark referred to earlier [12]. The wing consisted of twelve skin panels (six at the top of the wing and six at the bottom), three spars and four ribs (see Figs 6 and 7). Fig. 6
Wing box with overall dimensions (in mm) showing panels 1–6 (top of wing) Fig. 7
Panels 7–12 at the bottom of the wing, plus spars and ribs

The objective was to minimize the total mass of the wing by optimizing the layer thicknesses in each of the skin panels, subject to critical buckling and material strength constraints. No attempt was made to optimize the ribs and spars, which were included in the model to provide appropriate simply supported edge conditions for the panels.

A typical skin panel is shown in Fig. 8. For each panel, three L-shaped stringers provided increased longitudinal stiffness. Thus a total of ten plates were defined for each panel: four skin plates, three webs and three flanges. Fig. 8
Typical skin panel. Width of skin plates = 150 mm; Depth of flanges = 25 mm; width of flanges = 10 mm

High strength carbon-epoxy was used as the material for the individual laminae of all the component plates. Table 1 summarizes the material properties in the principal directions, together with the ultimate strengths and density. In this simplified demonstration, no allowance has been made for damage tolerance, imperfections, manufacturing constraints or laminate design rules. Table 1
Material properties of high strength carbon-epoxy
Longitudinal Young's Modulus E1 (N/mm2) 140000
Transverse Young's Modulus E2 (N/mm2) 10000
In-plane shear modulus G12 (N/mm2) 5000
Major Poisson's ratio v12 0.3
Ultimate longitudinal tensile strength max. σ1t (N/mm2) 1500
Ultimate longitudinal compressive strength max. σ1c (N/mm2) 1200
Ultimate transverse tensile strength max. σ2t (N/mm2) 50
Ultimate transverse compressive strength max. σ2c (N/mm2) 250
Ultimate in-plane shear strength max. τ12 (N/mm2) 70
Density ρ (g/mm3) 0.0016

Individual property cards were specified in the MSC/NASTRAN model for each of the component plates. As mentioned in section 3.1, this is an essential requirement for the model generation in Viconopt MLO, and allows the specification of separate design variables for each of these plates.

A uniform mesh consisting of 29 280 quadrilateral 4-noded QUAD4 shell elements [31] was generated for the overall wing, resulting in a model with 126 860 degrees of freedom. Although it would have been possible to specify a relatively coarse mesh at system level, a more refined mesh was deliberately chosen to test the performance of Viconopt MLO for larger scale problems.

To model realistic boundary conditions, the root of the wing was attached to a steel adapter (see Fig. 6) which was fully clamped at its root. The load case considered twisted the wing about its longitudinal axis. Simple point loads were applied at the tip of the wing with magnitudes shown in Fig. 9. Twelve VICONOPT panel models were generated. The panels were assumed to be simply supported along all four edges, so that out-of-plane and transverse in-plane displacements were fully constrained. With some approximation, the webs and flanges of the stringers were assumed to be unconstrained at their ends. Fig. 9
Loads on composite wing
Material strength constraints were specified for each panel according to the ultimate strength values summarized in Table 1.

When specifying the design variables, use was made of the symmetric lay-up option in Viconopt MLO. In total, 144 design variables were defined for the layer thicknesses with lower and upper bounds as shown in Table 2.

sec.title: 4.1 Optimization results
sec.p: Viconopt MLO carried out three optimization cycles, before the convergence criterion for the overall mass of the wing was satisfied. As expected, the load transfer between MSC/NASTRAN and VICONOPT indicated that the panels were required to carry loads mainly in the longitudinal direction. Panels 1 to 6 at the top of the wing were mainly subjected to compression (compression panels), while panels 7 to 12 at the bottom of the wing went into tension (tension panels).

Figure 10 shows the changes in mass throughout the optimization process. It can be seen that the overall mass of the wing converged well on a value of approximately 65 kg, which represented a total saving of 5 kg over the initial design. The compression panels all experienced an increase in mass. At the same time, the tension panels became significantly lighter. Fig. 10
Mass changes during the optimization process

Good convergence was noted for the masses of the individual panels, as well as the loading determined from the MSC/NASTRAN results for each panel. A detailed summary of the panel mass changes is given in Fig. 11. As expected, the panels at the tip of the wing are lightest, and the panel masses gradually increase towards the root. Owing to higher loads acting on the panels on the right of the wing (panels 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, and 12) the optimization process resulted in increased masses for these panels compared with the adjacent panels on the left. Fig. 11
Panel mass changes during the optimization process: (a) compression panels; (b) tension panels

Figures 12 and 13 show the stress contours for the final designs of all the panels. Since adjacent panels no longer have the same layer thicknesses, asymmetric stress distributions occur even for the first load case. The stress re-distributions are reflected by the loads calculated for the panels at the start of each new multilevel optimization cycle. Fig. 12
Stress contours for the final designs of panels 1–6 Fig. 13
Stress contours for the final designs of panels 7–12

Figures 14 and 15 provide an overview of how the axial loads and longitudinal bending moments on the individual panels are re-distributed during the optimization cycles. Fig. 14
Axial load re-distribution during the optimization process: (a) compression panels; (b) tension panels Fig. 15
Bending moment re-distribution during the optimization process: (a) compression panels; (b) tension panels

Owing to the buckling constraints, more material is assigned to the compression panels, resulting in increased stiffnesses. Typically, additional loads are then attracted to these panels. While this phenomenon can be noticed (e.g. for panels 2, 4, and 6 in Fig. 13), it does not appear to affect the convergence of the overall process.

A significant reduction of axial loads and longitudinal bending moments can be observed for the tension panels, which is owing to the load re-distribution across the overall wing, following the increased in-plane stiffness as well as the flexural rigidity of the compression panels.

For the design variables, a series of trends could be identified, even though full convergence on specific layer thicknesses was not always achieved by the optimization process. However, during each panel optimization carried out by VICONOPT, the design variables converged well onto a specific solution.

During the optimization process, the layer thicknesses in the tension panels were all reduced to values at or close to their lower bounds, while the tension was primarily supported by the 0∘ layers, as expected. Owing to transverse effects resulting from the way the twisting loads are applied at the tip of the wing, the thicknesses of the 90∘ layers in panels 7 and 8 are larger than for the panels in the middle section and at the root of the wing. For panels 9 to 12, the design of the webs and flanges are totally balanced, even though such restrictions had not been specified for the VICONOPT models.

The majority of the load in panel 1 is carried by the 0∘ and 90∘ layers, with some shear being carried by the ±45∘ layers. While most panels show good convergence on panel mass, it is not quite the case for this panel. Improvements could be achieved by introducing a panel mass convergence criterion; however, this would require some additional optimization cycles.

Panel 2 is immediately affected by the larger components of the twisting uplift, resulting in all of its 0∘ layers being taken to their upper bounds. The panel needs to carry significantly more shear, which has led to increased thicknesses of the ±45∘ layers in all plates.

The final designs for panels 3 and 4 are fairly uniform. In addition to the principal longitudinal compression, and compared to panels 1 and 2, an increased amount of shear and transverse loading needs to be carried. The thicknesses of the 0∘ and 90∘ layers in the skin and flanges are all taken to their upper bounds. The ±45∘ layers are increased in all plates, except in the webs. The significance of the shear and transverse loading for the design of the panels was assessed by means of separate VICONOPT models. Only the longitudinal compression and bending moments were applied, and any shear or transverse loading was omitted. As expected, this resulted in significantly lighter designs owing to smaller thicknesses of the ±45∘ layers.

Panels 5 and 6 are the most heavily compressed panels in the wing. Even though the panels are adjacent to each other, the final designs are of fundamentally different natures. In panel 6, the loads are carried by all the plates, including the webs. Almost all of the 0∘ and 90∘ layers are taken to their upper bounds, and the ±45∘ layers are required to carry shear loads. However, for panel 5, the bulk of the load is carried by the skin and the flanges, and most layer thicknesses in the web have been significantly reduced. To verify this design and to ensure VICONOPT had not been caught up in a local optimum, additional design studies were carried out for varying starting designs subjected to the loads developed in cycle 3. Regardless of the initial configuration, all solutions converged on a design similar to the one produced by the multilevel optimization process. While VICONOPT indicates a stable design, the proposed solution is clearly not acceptable from a manufacturing point of view. However, the problems encountered could be overcome by restricting the flanges and the webs to take the same thicknesses which can be achieved in VICONOPT using a ‘LINKING’ option. Design variable linking in VICONOPT is very versatile and goes much further than the plate equivalencing introduced in Viconopt MLO. This option has not been implemented in the current version of Viconopt MLO, but can be included by making manual additions to the automatically generated input files.
Although a simple rectangular geometry has been assumed here, skewed and tapered panels can also be modelled in VICONOPT by using suitably located point supports [32].
The stability of the final optimized configuration was confirmed by carrying out a buckling analysis on the whole wing using MSC/NASTRAN.

In terms of computational efficiency, comparing processing times with those for optimization using finite element analysis only techniques, the time saved using Viconopt MLO can be calculated as follows. Assume the times taken to complete static and buckling analyses using FEA are tMs and tMb respectively, a buckling design analysis in VICONOPT takes tVd, and the time required for all the Viconopt MLO processes in each design/analysis cycle, i.e. data conversion and convergence checking, is ϕ. For a multilevel optimization problem containing Np panels and taking Nd design cycles, the time taken for an initial buckling optimization using FEA analyses only will then be (9)
The time taken by using Viconopt MLO will be (10)

Based on the parameters given in Table 4 for the case study considered here this gives a total processing time of TFE=20722 s using FEA only and TMLO=5331 s for Viconopt MLO giving a saving of over 70 per cent. Table 4
Parameters of the example for efficiency calculation (Based on a Core™ 2 Duo, 2 GHz, 1.96GB RAM computer)
Parameters for Viconopt MLO Np 21
Nd 9
ϕ 240 s
Parameters for MSC/NASTRAN tMs 54.6 s
tMb 2302.4 s
Parameters for VICONOPT tVd 2.0 s

sec.title: 5 CONCLUDING REMARKS
sec.p: Although much of the structural engineering software currently used in industry originates in academia, users demand increasingly sophisticated interfaces for modelling and visualization of results. As a result, special purpose academic software has often struggled to gain acceptance in industry, not because of any lack of capability, efficiency or robustness, but because of the lack of investment in modern, user-friendly interfaces.

The present work provides such an interface, based on good windows software design principles. The interface, Viconopt MLO, couples the widely used FEM software MSC/NASTRAN and the specialist panel analysis and design program VICONOPT in order to provide a multilevel framework for optimization of lightweight structures such as aircraft wings. Such an approach harnesses the robustness of the FEM for analysis of the whole structure with the computational efficiency of exact strip methods for buckling analysis and optimum design of individual structural components, and is in line with recommendations from a European action group on aerospace structural optimization.

The feasibility of this multilevel approach to optimization has been illustrated by the optimum design of a simplified composite aircraft wing with 12 longitudinally stiffened panels. The optimization process was well converged, gave a stable configuration and has been shown to be computationally efficient. It is planned to develop further benchmark problems so that the method can be compared further with other approaches.

Other planned developments include allowance for stiffness and stress variations resulting from postbuckling of each of the component panels. Discrete valued design variables will be used, e.g. to satisfy the manufacturing constraints arising from the use of carbon fibre composite material, or to perform layup optimization. Convergence will be required on the mass and loading of each component panel. Also, design changes will be allowed at both system and panel levels, with the transfer of constraint and sensitivity information through the Viconopt MLO interface. In the longer term, links will be made to other analysis and design software, e.g. to include aeroelastic behaviour, so as to move towards the aerospace industry's goal of automated multidisciplinary optimization.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
ack.p: This work was funded by a Cardiff University Research Award. The first author would like to express his gratitude for the support received from Cardiff University, as well as the German National Scholarship Foundation.
